NOW LIVE ON KICKSTARTER https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1346069182/plexibots?ref=nav_search Actuator Mounts
The idea here is to place an off-the-shelf actuator into its corresponding adapter.
Then they can be attached onto our extrusion using our joining plates and angles.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213749
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213776
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213750
The stepper motor mount will accomodate NEMA 11, NEMA 14, and NEMA 17 Stepper Motors.
The geared DC motor mount will accomodate micro metal motors available on Pololu.com.
http://www.pololu.com/category/60/micro-metal-gearmotors
They are available in a wide range of combinations of RPM and output torque.
We have mounts to accomodate both mini and regular hobby servo motors.
http://www.pololu.com/product/693
http://www.pololu.com/product/2143
If you are interested in powering hinge joints or creating a crank shaft, check out

title: Anycubic mini - printing bed and easy leveler

description.text:
I've spent a lot of time in order to properly level my new Anycubic Kossel 3D printer. At the end, I've decided to make a new printing bed out of aluminium (3mm) and print "levelers" with a 3D printer and make the whole leveling process a lot easier, quicker and way more precise.

I've used Stepcraft 840 CNC machine for cutting my first prototype printing bed out of acrylic in order to test the design.

You can read a bit more about the process here http://stepcrafts.com/the-best-setup-for-cutting-plexiglass-acrylic-with-stepcraft/

Additional requirements:

6 x M4 screws 25-30mm length (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/M4-4mm-A2-Stainless-Steel-Pozi-Pan-Head-Machine-Screws-Pozidrive-Bolts-/160913853386)

12 x M4 Flat Washers (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/A2-STAINLESS-STEEL-FORM-A-FLAT-WASHERS-TO-FIT-METRIC-BOLTS-SCREWS-M1-6-TO-M30-/150802639052)

6 x Wing Nuts (http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/M4-4mm-STAINLESS-STEEL-A2-WING-NUTS-TO-FIT-BOLTS-AND-SCREWS-FREE-POST-/111316578640?var=&hash=item19eafc3150:m:miaH3WYXNsq-BPPKCL3nD7Q)

title: Boucle 50 mm x 55 mm Sac à dos Quechua Forclaz 30 L - Backpack buckle 50 mm x 55 mm

description.text:
These buckles were designed to match as closely as possible the original design of those originally clamped on my backpack. Also, they were designed with 3D printing in mind, hence i had to make changes to the primary functional design in the aim to print it better.

Here is the original CAD file location :
https://github.com/bebenlebricolo/3D-printing/tree/master/Backpack%20Buckles%2055mm/CAD%20files

At the moment stuff is still a bit messy, however feel free to share, improve and fork this project as you like. Just remember to respect the CERN OHL license terms under which i've licensed the files.

http://www.ohwr.org/attachments/2388/cern_ohl_v_1_2.txt here is a link redirecting to the official hosting website of the license.

You may also find its trace in this video, posted by Thomas Sanladerer where you can see the supports removal. Thanks to him.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OsQpxkLhDLk

---- Specifications ----
50 mm (actual 47 mm wide) x 55 mm Buckle - Replacement part - Decatlhon Forclaz 30 Litres
Both parts (male and female) + improved male part (2 more springs) and virtual assembly for validation purposes (design)

----EN----
I made a replacement part for the broken piece of my backpack. The original one have been overstressed and broke at the attachement area of the backpack strap.
Then i used my CAD software to make a replacement part, keeping as much as I could the original measures of the original part. I finally made a virtual assembly design to correct the little measurement mistakes, and make some improvements of the design.

---- Fr ----
J'ai conçu cette pièce en suivant les cotes de la pièce d'origine (qui provient d'un sac de randonnée de marque Décathlon, de la gamme Forclaz 30 L) pour remplacer la pièce d'origine (boucle femelle). Les deux boucles se veulent aussi proches que possible des pièces originales, en termes de design. J'ai également effectué un assemblage virtuel "à blanc" pour tester la conception, corriger les erreurs de mesures et effectuer quelques améliorations.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Rework

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 (best) or 0.2 mm

Infill:

100% (max rigidity)

Notes:

----EN----
These parts might by printed laying flat on the 3D printer bed (biggest side of the part). This will help the buckle to withstand mechanical stress thanks to the lining of the filament fibers (they should be aligned with the X axe of the part, then the mechanical load could be easily handled by the fibers).

---- Fr -----
Ces deux pièces doivent être imprimées à plat, selon leur plus grand côté. La répartition de la charge mécanique sera bien meilleure si les couches sont dans le même plan que le plan de la charge principale (plan xy, avec une composante majorante sur l'axe X).

Male buckle part (easy one)

Male buckle part :

Nothing too hard for this part. I ended with many functionnal parts using Cura and Sli3r. Just make sure to enable supports (and brim / raft for ABS because of the small footprint of the part).
I recommend using pillar structure with Slic3r as they are really easy to remove, and make sure to correctly tweak the gap distance between the support structure and the actual piece.

Support settings (Slic3r):
0.2 mm Z spacing and 2.5 mm pattern spacing.
3 interface layers.
ABS 220 deg Hot end / 70 deg bed

Female buckle (hard part)

This part is much more tricky than the male one.
Be sure to use supports, but with a big spacing pattern (15 mm for me) to make it easy to remove (the inside of the buckle is quite inaccessible ). I also used Honeycomb structure instead of pillars, and made the Z spacing and interface layers higher than the default values.

Support settings :
0.35 mm Z spacing
15 mm spacing
Honeycomb pattern
3 to 5 interface layers

Overhang threshold : 0 (set Slic3r to automatic mode, it saved my print! )

comments.text:
I printed this in PLA with supports. It fits together well and looks pretty good.
It fits a 1 1/2 inch webbing which will hold several hundred pounds.
This buckle is much too weak for this size of webbing and fails with about 10 lbs in PLA. Would be stronger in nylon but I can't see strong enough as it is right now. The weak point is where the male part attaches to the buckle.
comments.author: gerryw1000

comments.text:
Hi! Thanks for your feedback, i also noticed weak points at the base of the male's arms/teeth (don't know how to call them..).
They usually broke while bending the arms, never tried to put them on huge loads after all ^^'
At the moment i unfortunately don't have the time to improve those points and i only tried to reproduce the original design as is.
I read we could improve the PLA resistance by heating it for quite a while at low to medium temperatures, haven't try it yet though.

comments.text:
Hello ! I finally made the male piece, with slic3r and a 0.3mm resolution, 210 degrees PLA and the result is much better than expected. I had no difficulty to break the support pieces and even if the structure is a bit rough, it looks quite satisfying to me.
Although, I spent most of the preparation time choosing the right setup parameters for the print...
Have you managed to get yours right ?
comments.author: charliepsycho

comments.text:
Hi,
Yes the Male piece prints fine, although like I say, I reckon shaving the webbing grip down a bit looking at the voids would mean it would print upside down without any support at all!
The hard part is the female part, as the side-walls are a bit thin to be self standing when they print (they disintegrate and are not strong enough to withstand pressure from insertion) and of course the bridging is really large (although surprisingly that's structurally fine, just messy internally.) Again, printing upside down and flattening the down side would mean no supports required.
I printed in ABS @ .25 with 235 deg extrusion and 95 deg bed at 100mm/s
comments.author: bebenlebricolo

comments.text:
Hi sir! I finally got the perfect pieces i was heading for these last days.
I used .3 mm layer, 220 deg ABS / 70 deg bed 60 mm /s with nicely tweaked support materials (Slic3r 's honeycomb with 15 mm pattern spacing and automatic overhang threshold).
Seems to be working quite well and both pieces are perfectly functionnal.
Made some continuous improvements on male ( 2 mm longer and wider) and female part (thicker side walls and thicker base part to withstand a greater stress).
Again, thanks for your precious feedback, you spotted right!
comments.author: charliepsycho

prüfen, da ich bei meinem immer 0,5 mm dazugeben muss.

Das heist : Lager hat 19mm so habe ich 19,5mm eingestellt.

Ich habe 10 DVD Laufwerke von HP zerlegt , gleiches Model nur von 2006 bis 2011.
HIer waren nur das Model 2008 und 2009 gleich.

Wünsche viel Spass.

https://youtu.be/5c168Yv2bdA

description.text:
Parametric v-slot slide nut SCAD file for 20 series extrusion.

Printed nuts work just like the metal ones you get in printer kits or on eBay. Screw the nut on first, place the nut in the extrusion and tighten. The nut rotates 90° in the slot to lock it in place.

The included STL files are for 3mm screw threads but you can also download the SCAD and DXF files to create your own.

This support will attach directly on the Mavic battery. It is easy to remove and can be used to add a GSM tracker on your drone. In my case I use my support combined with a dedicated RF-V16 support I already found here, but you should stick your tracker directly on my support, using double side tape…
The problem I attempted to solve, is the fact we can't install the GSM tracker above the Mavic inboard compass which are located at the top front and back (compass 2 and 1) of the drone body … If you do so you'll get compass errors ! This point can be easily checked with DJi GO app …

So my support allows to have your tracker above the battery …

title: shopping cart euro coin key chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Print and keep one of these in your keychain. When at your favorite supermarket, use this to release a shopping cart/trolley. Pull it back and put again in your pocket. Happy shopping !

This is my first 3d printer design back in 2014. The idea of course is not mine, I think there used to be dummy coins for shopping carts like these long before 3d printers were invented.
This design is from scratch. I simply measured a euro coin and placed a tag for your keychain.

This is my favorite print to hand out to friends and loved ones. It prints fast with no special settings. Both 0.2 and 0.3 slicer resolutions work nice. I have printed in PLA, ABS, PETG, all work great.

These are body post stiffeners for the Tamiya MF-01 Chassis. Specifically the Suzuki Jimny but will work for others too.

This is a fully printable case for a word-clock. It is designed for use of LED stripes WS281x with 60 LED/m.
Additional there are needed only a RaspberryPi, a 5V power-supply, some wires and the software from here: https://github.com/xSnowHeadx/word-clock
If using an additional USB-soundcard the device can be used as spectrum-analyzer too (see third picture).

Edit 2017/02/28: wordclock_case_half.stl updated

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print two pieces of the half outer case. On the bottom of the case there are marks for the placement of the LED stripes.
For the grid laying direct on the LED stripes use the parts "bottom_grid". They have slots for the stripes and wires. You need two of them. The upper grids are without slots for better shadowing. Here are 4 pieces necessary. These parts are not at double height to give the possibility for placing additional diffusor foils between them when using a clear shade. Print the grids with black material.
The size of the shades is 184x184mm. If your printer has a sufficient build volume you can use the single parts. If not, use the halved parts. The grids are generally halved for better insertion in the case.

I uploaded all thinkable variants of the shades for your convenience. They must be printed with a resolution of 0.2mm and usually with the plate downwards. The first two layers (the plate) must be printed with a transparent or translucent material. After the second layer the filament has to be changed to black.
The types "normal" can be used, when the letters should be visible even if they are not lighted to show the functionality.
The "mirror" types can be used to hide the letters and show only the lighted. With a translucent white plate and a turquois light setting (RGB 0%,78%,100%) there is an "Apple-effect" possible as to see in the photos.
If you want to use your own print strategy I uploaded the shade for the letters and the plate for the shade separate.
If you don't want to print the shade with the 3D-printer you can print the attached wordclock_shade_laserprinter.bmp with a laserprinter on an overhead-foil and use this as shade. Then you should use additional diffusor foils between the grid layers. This looks like the last photo above. It is recommended to stack two or three of the laserprinted foils for better shadowing.
The wiring of the LED starts at the lower left corner and continues as meander from the lower to the upper stripe (see "word-processor.c" in the source files). It is recommended to draw an additional power connection directly from the lower to the uppermost stripe for evenly brightness of the LED all over the area.

How to convert an image to stl :

Step 1:
Select a monochrome picture in google image (jpg/png/...)

Step 2:
With "Gimp" software :
With the "magic wand", select the background > click right > reverse selection > ctrl + x > ctrl + v. And in layers list: "create a new layer", select the background layer and remove it.
Save as png format

Step 3:
With "Inkscape" software, open the png and save picture in svg

Step 4:
Upload the picture in http://svg2stl.com/ and download the STL

Easy :)

title: iPhone 7 Plus Arca Swiss Pano Mount

description.text:
I was looking for a way to allow me to rotate my iPhone 7 Plus close to the center (nodal?) point of the lens to make better 360 images. Remembered that I had an aftermarket Arca Swiss tripod head plate. I knew this would allow me to adjust the position of the lens.

I found this mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1702643 . I made it a little larger (38 x 60) to fit my aftermarket plate and it works great.

I added an offset mount to slide my phone into. The small notches are what I estimate to be the center points of the lens.

It fits an iPhone 7 Plus with an Apple silicone case perfectly.

Appears to be a success. Initial testing creating a 360 image indoors with objects close to the camera using DMD Panorama shows no stitching errors!!

description.text:
This is a remix of Punkkills 105 micro FPV quadcopter that I designed to be cheap, easy to build, and a good FPV quad for beginners. In his article on the micro 105 FPV quadcopter he mentioned that this drone could be made using a Hubsan flight controller and transmitter and this is what I did. I was able to build this quadcopter with everything need for a FPV quadcopter for around $120. A build guide for the quadcopter can be found here https://www.instructables.com/id/Cheap-105-Micro-Quadcopter-1/ on Instructables.

Note: T-gaze is optimal filament for this design because of it's durability.

comments.text: Really sorry but my specific build is only compatible with Hubsan Transmitter. Because I tried to go as cheap as possible I used a Hubsan flight controller and transmitter which means a DSM2 would not be compatible. If you really want to try I would look into this https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2259817-My-review-of-the-Hubsan-Protocol-Radio-Adapter. Sorry I couldn't help more.

description.text:
Update 4/10/2017

Updated the frame yet again. Weights about the same, but is a lot more crash resistant.

Update 3/5/2017

I have updated the frame to account for varying shaft lengths in the 8520 motors. I have found there are two basic lengths, so this design allows the motor to be raised or lowered as need.

I have also added a new camera mount for this camera: http://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-Eachine-AIO-5_8G-40CH-25MW-VTX-800TVL-13-Cmos-FPV-Camera-Upgraded-for-QX90-QX95-Racing-Quadcopter-wp-Usa-1086282.html?rmmds=myorder which has a picture far superior to the stock cam that came with my QX90.

I am also using this flight controller which has an integrated RX, but this frame will support most micro controllers: http://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-Eachine-FRF3_EVO-Brushed-Flight-Control-Board-Built-in-FRSKY-Compatible-SBUS-8CH-Receiver-wp-Usa-1091779.html?rmmds=myorder

These are the motors i have been using:
http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Tiny-QX90-Micro-FPV-Racing-Quadcopter-Spare-Parts-8_5x20mm-Coreless-Motor-p-1079157.html?rmmds=myorder

This is the V2 version of the original i created: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2071183

Here's a video i made this morning: https://youtu.be/HY3A0PO7R4A (also known as 'how to annoy your wife')

Major improvements are that it is a little lighter (.5g); a little stronger and allows access to the USB port while mounted.

This model is a modified version of osliang's quad which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1700311 . i dont think i could have started this project without that original project.

I have moved the camera further forward and the frame is lighter at just under 10g (without cam mount & tray). All loaded up with battery and stock QX90 parts (as in the photos) its just under 58g which is heavier than the original QX90 (which weighs i think 54g).

It seems to fly really well.

I have included the Solidworks design files. If you make changes, let me know. I might want to add those to my model.

This has been designed for the 8.5mm motors.

I printed this in ABS with 30% fill (fill is barely used) except the VTX guard which i printed at 0% fill so its hollow and lighter.

Also, it WILL require supports to print.

Good luck.

comments.text: Just a quick note on food safety.  While you used "food safe"plastic, 3d printing leaves voids between the layers and individual strands.  These voids are the problem not the plastic.  In the foodservice industry we are prohibited from using wooden cutting boards for that specific reason.  Food particles can and will get into those microscopic voids and allow for growth of food borne bacteria allowing for cross contamination.  Hot dogs come pre- cooked which reduces the danger, unlike a cookie cutter which should be disposed of after use.
comments.author: adamcooks

comments.text: I know this is sort of off topic but I just wanted to say that your comment about wooden cutting boards is incorrect. I worked in the foodservice industry for years and wooden cutting boards are commonly used, especially in high end restaurants. Properly used they are very sanitary. I do agree though that the voids in 3d printed stuff is a problem for food, that is exactly why you have to throw out many plastic cutting boards over time, they get grooves cut into them that you can't properly clean.
comments.author: adamcooks

comments.text: Quick question. If I were to use a heat gun or some form of extreme heated air, can and would the voids close or at least get small enough to be safe? Thanks!

Create under DAZ3D, to resemble the character as much as possible,
There are some dress inconsistencies,
Because I did not have boots available for free.

Supports are to be added before printing,
The current position of the character in the STL file is the best compromise for printing with minimal support.

Yes

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You need to create support.

Bushing to fit a Chicago screw to a 608 skate bearing. Add a small amount of weight to your fidget spinner, or just dress it up a little.

A second version of the bushings is available that leaves indentations in the bushings so that additional weight can be easily added underneath the Chicago screws to balance the spinner.

Printing multiples (instead of one at a time) works well and will save time. Print resolution isn't critical, as the part doesn't show. Low resolution works fine. As the parts are small, adhesion of the print is important.

Use a 7mm Chicago screw (use 6mm if you really want to snug it up against the bearing).

You might find that the Chicago screws takes your spinner out of balance, which will add quite a bit of wobble and decrease spin time. In that case, you may wish to use the balancer bushings. Use a prop balancer (e.g. this one from Amazon) and add weight to the indentations in the bushing to balance the spinner. Tungsten putty works well for this purpose.

description.text:
I saw this thing and thought we need a customizer version of this frame.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1961848

Please see the full description on his thing.

I made a small change to the pin hole so it might fit better on a printer with a bit of back lash artifact in the corners.

Features:

  1. Give it the length of the T-Frame and build higet of your printer and it will output a set of frames to glue together.
  2. Change the tolerance value to make the pin and hole fit better on your printer.
  3. It will auto place the T-Frames.
  4. (Not implemented yet) Give it the size of the build plate to place the T-Frames better. For now it will just put them in a square.

Check out these for accessories:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10261
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13599
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1961848

comments.text:
Great design!
Before I print them could you please explain what are FA, FS and print tolerances. I am a bit fuzzy about them.
Thanks a lot in advance.
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text:
The description of FA and FS form OpenSCAD:
$fa is the minimum angle for a fragment. Even a huge circle does not have more fragments than 360 divided by this number. The default value is 12 (i.e. 30 fragments for a full circle). The minimum allowed value is 0.01. Any attempt to set a lower value will cause a warning.

comments.text:
I ran into a small problem with this part, but this is due to a modification that I have made. I have replaced my bronze print nozzles with hardened A2 print nozzles made by Micro Swiss. The threaded ends of the upgrade print nozzles are about 1mm longer than the original bronze ones, which in turn makes my print head about 1mm longer. When I did the upgrade I had to reset the Z home screw, but didn't think about it when I printed this part. My heater blocks actually push on the vent ring pretty hard. I simply need to make the part a little longer to make it work with my setup.
I just wanted to identify this as a potential problem so that other makers don't make the same mistake that I did.

author: techtutor

description.text: Fixed the front Print From 16850 to 18650 and resized to to hold Regular cells without the protection cap.

title: Anet A6 Spacer y-axis belt clip

description.text:
The original version results in different belt strains. With the new spacer, you get a constant belt strains. Have a look at the pictures to understand the difference and how to mount the spacer.

There are two versions of the spacer you could download. One 15mm and one 9mm. Which one to choose depends on how you have mounted your slider-frame. If you have mounted it like in the pictures, you need the 15mm version. If you have mounted the brace of the frame other way around you need the 9mm version.

You need 4 longer M4 screws,

  • at least 25mm for the 15mm spacer
  • or 20mm for the 9mm spacer

comments.text: Excellent....I just got my a6 and i was wondering why i was having trouble keeping my bed alignment. It's the damn belts pulling down on the bed as it gets towards the ends. I dont know why they even let the a6 out the door without this part. Great job. Simple but awesome!
comments.author: Xalky

title: Banana Keytar - Laser Cut Acrylic, PVC

description.text:
Laser cut pieces for a Banana Keytar frame. We used a Circuit playground and clipped bananas to the capacitive touch pads. We generated random colors, and flashed these as notes were played. Pieces were cut on a laser with a 32 x 20 bed.

The initial thought was to put a Pi with touchscreen in the large rectangular front hole. It fits perfectly, but we couldn't get the internet to be reliable at the hackathon. I'll do another build in my shop and document the assembly.

With Pi, the process would be Bananas - Capacitive Touch Pads - Use the Circuit Playground as a MIDI controller - USB in to Raspberry Pi 3 - Map pads on an online synth program - Bluetooth sound out to speaker.

CAD - Corel - Laser

I started with a CAD model of the top panel. It's free to fork and modify on Onshape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d05c7a8f6e9a6bab922b9b76/w/1d7e83d76073245a1de53ad2/e/3f9dd5e9602a8d73441620d6

Then I exported as a DXF, opened in Corel, and used our laser plugin to cut the acrylic pieces.

BOM (in progress)

1 20 X 32 Sheet of Acrylic

FRAME:
1 10ft length of 3/4" PVC
3 3/4 PVC elbow connectors
1 3/4 PVC T connector
1 3/4 PVC end cap
1 Box (~25) #6 wood screws

SHOULDER STRAP:
2 1/4-20 x 1" bolts (or similar)
6 1/4-20 nuts (jam nuts would be best, regular work)
1 guitar strap

ELECTRONICS:
1 Circuit Playground
1 Raspberry Pi 3, with SD Card
1 7" Pi touchscreen display, mounted to Pi 3
1 USB data cable
1 10000mAh battery pack with USB cable
Bluetooth Speaker or Speaker with 3.5 mm headphone jack and cable
Lots of alligator clips

MISC:
Adhesive wire tie blocks
Zip ties
Packing (clear) tape
Double stick tape (thick, like foam tape or the 3M clear mounting tape)

  • Alternative: Command Strips
Synth Information

We used the online synth on Websynths.com
No real engineering went into this choice, except it was free and easy to use. If you use this, make sure to change your number of pads to 8, and the lowest MIDI input to 36. The channel should also be 10. The blue indicator light on the MIDI tab on the site should blink as you press a key.

Design for Disassembly

I cut all of the big parts for this project at the makerspace in SC and then brought it all to NYC for assembly and programming at a hackathon.

All the parts and tools needed to fit in carry-on or checked baggage, so it made sense to use a PVC frame that could be easily disassembled and thrown into a roller bag. I carried the flat laser cut sheets on the plane sandwiched between a piece of foam core cut in half, and they sat fine at the top of the overhead bins.

It was originally designed to use cucumbers, but they don't come in bunches and are more expensive. Initial Layout and Material Cutting

I chose the overall dimensions based on the capacity of our laser cutter and so I could get both the front and back panels off of the same sheet of acrylic.

I cut the PVC and adjusted the lengths by removing material as needed. Remember that fittings will add length to a side. If you intend to take it apart and reassemble after you drill mounting holes for the panels, make sure to mark the alignment of pipe to fittings - it's really hard to get the rotation to line up again if you don't.

Figuring out the frame. This size is great for my sister and I, but we're tall. When I bring this to science fairs it is way too big and heavy for kids, so I end up just putting it on a table and using it as a keyboard. Marking approximate locations with a dry erase marker. I drew everything out before I drew it in CAD.

description.text:
I worked on the Robbie Robot model another Maker uploaded here (one piece) to have a better body and new, more realistic arms.
Thanks a lot to Cerberus333 for his model.
I made the arms very light and fast to print, you have to put it vertically near the body when you create your Gcode.
So you have the possibility to move the head, body and arms, and to print them with different filaments.
Next step I'll reconstruct the head with the interior mechanism and a transparent shell (to be printed separately). NEW UPDATE December 31: I reconstructed all the Robby robot head, considering 45 degrees printing and all the possibile solution to increase the quality of printing. Now you have the head in one separated file (you can change just the head if you still downloaded the first version), and the glass dome in another one. That's because the robot is nice also without the glass dome, that will be very difficult to print with good results in transparent PLA or other similar materials, as Cerberus333 also said (please check his comment).

comments.text:
As I don't have pics currently, I will describe as best as I can.
I use plastic plates which i can get at the party stores and walmart etc.
the outer rim of the plate allows me to not need a "frame"
I have a small bucket with the bottom cut out.
the top of the bucket fits the inside flat area of the plastic plate.
i mount the bucket to a single burner electric hotplate.
this allows me to have a adjustable heat source.
i turn on the burner and put the plate on the top of the bucket
i continue to move/rotate the plate untill the center gets soft
my vaccum table is a metal cookie tin, with holes drilled
the side of the tin has a hole for the vaccum hose
simply move the plate to the tin with the vac on to make the cast.
now the dome of the robot i would make a form to draw the plate over
allow extra space around the dome to give the plastic space
to draw Make the mold able to be removed from the plastic
(no undercuts or other geometries that would make removal a problem).
When making the plastic cast, I recomend chilling the plastic form
in the freezer to make it less likely to stick to the sheet
Hope this made sense.
Also t-glass makes a pretty decent frosted glass , but not like a bubble,

title: Hanging Display and Arduino Ramps Mount for 25mm 8020 T-Slot Aluminum Extrusion Frame - LCD 12864 Graphic Smart Display Controller, Arduino Mega 2560, Ramps 1.4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I took my previous designs for an LCD mount and a RAMPS mount, both of which were angled 45deg and protruding from the top of my aluminum extrusion, and combined them into a single design which hangs down vertically from the top cross beam of my printer. I designed it so that there is clearance even on the rare occasions my X Axis is raised that high for a very tall print, your printer will vary so be sure to check this.

I am including STEP files for this reason, so they will be easier to modify. Please link back and respect licensing requirements if you remix the design for your own needs.

It is designed to fit the LCD 12864 Graphic Smart Display Controller found here and the standard Arduino Mega and RAMPS 1.4 printer controller setup.

Hardware Needed

  • (4) M3x25 bolts with 4 M3 nuts and washers (to hold display front piece to back plate)
  • (3) M3x12 bolts with 3 M3 nuts and washers (to hold Arduino board to back plate)
  • (2) M6x12 bolts with 2 M6 washers and T-nuts (for attaching to Aluminum extrusion)

Notes
This is designed for 25mm extrusion. I have the bolts holding the electronics on the back as attaching to the Arduino. The RAMPS is then held to the Arduino naturally by the pins' friction. One of the bolt hole clearances is tight, I could not actually fit a washer in there. You could also use longer bolts on the back and run them through the RAMPS board if you wanted.

description.text:
I tried printing the original design, but the center crossmember always printed funky, and you can actually see that in one of the "Made it" photos on the original design. I took the original and re-drew it in Sketchup, cleaning it up a bit and make the center crossmember solid. Turned out great.

I also scaled the model up to 113% to fit the larger Mini Countryman cupholders. I would suggest measuring your cupholder bottoms before printing so you can set the scale correctly.

CTC 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.10

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed in white ABS.

I printed with 3 top/bottom/side layers. You might be able to knock this down.
I did have to take a razor blade to the model to clean up some of the lines. This is probably due to my slurry being a little too thick.

print_settings.Notes:: Print a few of them at the same time, or you will have cooling issues. Smallest possible layer height.

description.text:
This is a pentagram token for use with boardgames or similar. I designed it for The Others: 7 Sins. It comes in a few different flavors. If you don't care and just want to start printing, I recommend pentagram-token-standing-minimal_supports.stl. Read on for full description.

Behold, the ultimate pentagram boardgame token. I had a lot of fun trying to come up with a nice looking pentagram token that was also printable. It was really hard to get it right. The devil is in the details... ...sorry.

It comes in a edgy 3d-looking version, and a flat version. For printability, there are two main approaches, the standing (complete) version, and the separated version that requires super-gluing the pentagram to the base.

3d version

pentagram-token-separated-with_support-fixed - Printable as is, requires gluing, but will have a nicer circle and star shape, at the cost of making one side of the star rough. This one will have the nicest result overall but needs some sanding on the supports side after printing.
pentagram-token-separated-no_support-fixed - As above, but supports are not pre-modeled.
pentagram-token-standing_no_support - The purest model, and least printable. Requires adding support
pentagram-token-standing-minimal_supports - Adds minimal support so it is printable, but will have some overhang issues
pentagram-token-standing-full_supports - adds full support so it is very printable standing.

Flat version

pentagram-token-standing-straight - Should print ok, some overhang issues
pentagram-token-separated-straight-fixed - Flat version for glueing, should have the least artifacts of all versions, but no 3d effect :(

Notes:

Print a few of them at the same time, or you will have cooling issues. Smallest possible layer height.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194066 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=194066

Using the following options: height = 2.5
z1 = 0
min_wall = 0.7
len = 4
thickness = .25
width = 2.5
radius = .5

For complete model print 2x Front_Flap, 2x Slider and 2x Handle. and one of everything else.
Everything prints without supports with exception of Outer_shell both back and front. For Me, Outer shells and Flaps required also adding 1mm brim.

  • Front_Flap, Front_Shell, Outer_shell_front, Outer_shell_back printed in white PLA
  • Lens printed in Transparent PLA with 40% honeycomb infill, 2 layers on bottom, 3 perimeters and no top layers
  • Everything else printed in black PLA.
    Whole of Wheatley printed in 0.10 resolution, Box/Stand printed with 0.20

For electronics (some soldering required):

  • 1206 Blue LED,
  • 51 Ohm resistor,
  • SS13T40 sliding switch,
  • 2032 battery,
  • BH2032 battery holder (like this one http://imgur.com/oJofXZJ)
  • Some wires to connect.

You can of course use different parts but it was designed with these parts in mind.

If you want to skip electronics I'd recommend printing Core_right_B instead of regular one, and battery_filler to fill space where battery would be, and printing lens in blue instead of transparent.

Order of assembly:

  1. Solder resistor, LED and 2 wires, fed wires through holes in LED_plate. Glue LED (hotglue or CA) in center of LED_plate (marked by 2 small bumps).
  2. With CA, glue together LED_plate with Lens (make sure to keep them aligned)
  3. Solder one wire to battery holder second one to the switch and use another bit of wire to connect switch with battery (keep in mind polarity of the LED and battery).
  4. Use bit of hot glue to secure switch in designated slot in Core_right. If LED lights up proceed to next steps
  5. With CA, glue Lens and battery holder to the Core_right.
  6. Glue Core_left to the Core_right
  7. Glue Core to the Outer_shell_back
  8. Glue each slider to a Front_Flap ( It's recomended to sand with fine grid sandpaper both sides of slider+flap to assure smoth sliding)
  9. Place both sliders in position then glue Outer_shell_front to the Core (make sure to not get any glue on the sliders)
  10. Glue Front_shell to the Core
  11. Glue both handles in the notches of Outer_shell
  12. Enjoy completed Wheatley.

Box/Stand was designed to snap together with 6 2x5mm round neodymium magnets. When gluing those in, make sure to align their polarity so box can stick together to secure Wheatley inside.

author: Joshb60796

description.text:
Got a common fringe at work and your milk is always empty although you didn't consume much? Better lock your milk! This thing will keep your milk save from your colleges!

A standard milk carton of approx. 6x9x19 cm (length x width x height) fits in perfectly.
To build this you need in addition to the printed parts:
-24x locknuts M5
-6x woodscrews 2.5 mm x 13 mm
-1m threaded rod M5 (cut it in 4 pieces of 20 cm)
-1x hinge (3 holes for screws with a pitch of 25 mm)
-a little lock (clamp diameter should be smaller 5 mm)
You may find those parts in your favorite hardware store.

The assembly is quite time consuming because of all the locknuts. I used an electric screwdriver and the two attached fork spanner. Those are not necessary! I started mounting the threaded rods on the bottom part. Next the middle was inserted. The top part should be joined with the lid before mounting it on the threaded rods. The hinge is connected to the top part using 3 woodscrews. The other 3 woodscrews are needed to connect top and lit. They must be trimmed to approx. 5 mm.

The top part should be printed with support enabled. For the lid it depends on your printers bridging performance whether you need support or not.

print_settings.Notes:: Housing

description.text:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2107631 designed by guerillacaterpillar

This is a 4-part toothless herb grinder with catchment tray.

Included in the files are a few alternative versions of each part.

  1. Knurled. This will take the longest to print. The Top and Housing will take ~6 hours each at 0.1mm layer height. The rifling may challenge some 3D printers.

  2. Plain. The outside surfaces of these pieces are smooth, allowing for fast print times.

  3. Rifled. This is about half way in between Knurled and Plain in terms of time.

I've also included grinding plates with 5, 6, and 7mm holes, with flaring and without (to allow the herb to move more easily).

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm to 0.3mm

Infill:

Variable.

Notes:

Layer Height and Print Speed

Knurled parts should be printed at 0.1mm and likely at a lower print speed depending on your printer.

Rifled and Plain parts can be printed at greater layer heights.

Density

The Top and Grinding Plate should be printed at medium density (20%) with thick walls.

The Tray and Housing can be printed at low density (5-10%).

Rafts and Supports

Depending on your printer you may want to use rafts and supports when printing the Housing due to its small contact area and overhanging tabs that support the grinding plate.

title: Hitman Raspberry Pi 3 Pi 2 VESA 75mm Case

description.text:
I am a huge fan of 0110-M-P's Raspberry Pi Case. I wanted to do a fun remix and as a huge fan of Agent 47, I decided to do a Hitman styled Remix.

There are a few differences between my case and the original outside the Hitman Theme:

  1. After printing the case in black, I noticed I couldn't see the power led on my Pi 3. I modified the lid to allow the power led to shine through (to right of SD).

  2. I removed the ribbon cable slots as I didn't need them for my application and they took away from the aesthetics. If anyone is interested in this case with the slots, let me know and I'll make a second one.

Grill Disclaimer: I do not know how much air flow the RasPi needs for operation, so use this grill at your own discretion.

The feet and bracket in the picture are not part of this remix. They are part of a mounting bracket that allows you to quickly pop on/off anything with a 75mm VESA mount. You can view that HERE.

title: HHKB Style 60% Keyboard Plate for Cherry MX and Alps, Costar and Cherry Stab compatible

description.text:
This is a keyboard plate for 60% keyboards.

This is a true HHKB (Happy Hacker Keyboard) style plate, including the 6u spacebar.
Thickness is 1.7mm, but the plate cut on the laser cutter shown is 2mm and works as well. 1.7mm is just what is specified for Cherry MX switches and 2mm is at the upper limit.

It does allow for Switch Top removal of both switch types for easy modding.

Plate supports Costar, Cherry Plate Mount and Cherry PCB mount stabilizers. I used costar in my build, but its nice to be able to switch to Cherry Plate Mount down the road.

title: Desktop Sword
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For display on your desk or shelf, I present a sword and scabbard.

The sword assembles much like a real sword would (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=snqNl6U2OLE). I am also including a template for the tsuba so people with more talent than me can make even fancier ones.

The tolerances on this model are all VERY tight. Almost everything will need some sanding to make it fit right.

This is a long model, you will need to use mesh mixer or netfab to cut it into pieces that your printer can handle.

I did the knots with shoelaces and looked up on youtube how to tie them.

Assembly

All the parts slide on from the handle end.

  1. The Habaki slides on first. As you can see in the video there is a small notch to line up with the 'sharp' edge of the blade.
  2. Slide the tsuba on with the thicker edge (see video) facing the 'sharp' edge
  3. Slide the handle on also with its thicker edge toward the 'sharp' edge
  4. Cap the handle with the kashira
  5. put the pins in to hold it all in place.

author: werewolf_fr

print_settings.Notes:: Plenty of cooling needed for the wheel or it will sag on the top lip

description.text:
This is a 60mm (ish) pulley for 12mm rope. I use these a lot on my sailboat and they break when you least expect it, I thought I would see if I could print one and see how long it lasts!

This design uses an M8 35mm through bolt, 22mm 608zz Stainless bearings (skateboard bearings) and a 6mm wide jaw shackle. I used stainless as they last forever on a boat.

I wouldn't warrant this is as good as a Harken block! But it takes my weight fine and seems pretty good. Early tests showed weakness in the wheel on extreme weight (which would split) I have tried a nylon one (which worked fine) and also tried surface treating the wheel with thin superglue, which also seems to work fine, but ultimately this is a light use guide pulley only.

Printer:

XYZ Davinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Plenty of cooling needed for the wheel or it will sag on the top lip

The two cheeks and the block are best acetone welded together. Sand the top of the block to get rid of any printing marks, dip in in acetone and place it on the cheek lining it up nicely. I then do the other side and bolt it together, leaving it for half an hour to weld. sand it smooth over the weld and with the shackle it seems as strong as it needs to be.

The block responds well to sanding and an acetone wipe and becomes a lovely thing to simply hold!

The wheel is designed to be very slightly oversized, such that you sand the faces on a flat surface (particularly the top which will have some roughness to it) then once the bearings are in fit it and rotate it in the block, sanding the outside edge, removing any roughness and imperfections in the print, once done you get a really nice fit to the block.

22mm bearings press into the wheel, one either side. Use a vice and a piece of card to protect the print. I've also done a plastic bearing to use whilst waiting for the Stainless ones, it doesn't last long in use, but it does to line things up.

Before and after sanding

comments.text: nice project man, do u use 2 bearings at wheel or just one?
comments.author: JeanRodrigues

comments.text:
Hi,
Yes, well spotted, it's designed for 2 bearings (the smaller ones use a single bearing.
I have run them with a single bearing and it didn't fail, but it was under a very light load, I think the wheel would pull off centre quite quickly without the second bearing.
Have fun...
...(c)

title: Adjustable BLTouch Clone and E3D clamp mount hotend

description.text:
BLTouch mount for E3d and chinese hotends.

For some reason the knockoff cheap chinese hotend from my Sunhokey would not fit into the E3d mount but the E3d would. Now I am not for sure that my E3d is not a clone but its much shorter then the chinese hotend.

I made two different versions so I could use either. Fan mount is for 40mm fan.

Since the chinese hotend is taller you can flip the mount around so that the bltouch can reach the bed or vice versa..

You can use the hotend mount with or without the bltouch mount..

remixed_from.title: BLTouch Adjustable Mount for Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3

remixed_from.author: pjvpjv
remixed_from.title: Folger i3 2020 Print Cooling Fan Assembly

description.text:
This is a "mashup" of two files, the BLTouch adjustable mount for Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3 and the Folger i3 Print cooling fan assembly. I shortened the space between the fan and probe holder. I have tested the BLTouch mount portion of this and it works very well. The original version warped a little and held the probe at a slight angle but still worked OK. I did this both in Meshmixer and Tinker cad-found tinker cad the easier of the two to use, results were essentially the same though. Thanks to the original developers of the source files, The adjustable BLTouch mount is outstanding and the fact that it uses a spring out of a pen is brilliant- no browsing through the hardware store!

UPDATE: Ihave abandoned the use of the fan shroud. After some experimentation, I realized that the standard 40X40X10 mm fans just do not generate enough pressure to provide any real cooling. I will probably adapt this mount to use a radial type blower fan in the future or maybe try a 40X40X20 fan. Still love the BLTouch side of this!

UPDATE 4/20/2017: I have successfully attached this fan duct, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620630 by Arjjck (V2), to this BLTouch Mount utilizing this mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2016131 by fldjjones. I did have to fabricate a spacer to go between the fan and BLTouch mount to correctly position the mount in the fore and aft direction. The blower style fan works great. I have had to reduce fan speed considerably to keep from cooling the nozzle too much. Thaks again for everyone involved for the original designs!

title: Side view mirror actuator shaft and gear replacement

description.text:
Have you ever broke your side view mirror by pushing the mirror in too hard ?
The mirror mirror itself wasn't cracked or shattered, but the gear behind the mirror was broken instead. Taken apart the mirror and see the broken shaft and gear, am so glad I have a 3D printer !

Side view mirror don't come in parts, you can't just buy the shaft or gear itself, dealer sell brand new one cost like $300 for the whole side view mirror assembly, ebay search for mirror actuator cost $50+, 3D printed parts cost less than a dollar.

If you have the same side view mirror actuator and need these parts, welcome to download and try see if it work for you.

comments.text: I have a Winnebago MH with Velvac Mirrors.  The actuator shaft matches.  Great Job!  The only issue is that the original part has a deeper well between the walls except for the center where you have the center indent correct.  It is about 1 mm deeper than the part that you designed.  This causes the shaft to ride higher on the two tabs on each side of the clip that goes through the center cup and holds the spring reducing the range of motion. author: xenz

description.text:
Why is it we only see improvements for things after they are installed or mounted? I must have installed and removed a recent VESA mount RasPi case 10+ times. That was my inspiration for this bracket.

This was designed for my Hitman Raspberry Pi Case but should work with any 75mm VESA mounted device. With the obvious exception of weight. Please don't try to hang a monitor with this bracket.

My goal when designing this was to be able to print it in PLA without any support, and have it work right off the printer. I hit both those goals with the exception of a couple small cuts needed by an exacto knife. I included some tiny supports into the design of the feet holding tabs, in order for them to work properly the little supports have to be cut (see picture).

On previous designs, the holding tabs kept breaking on me - this design seems to be solid. If you experience tabs breaking, you may try another PLA or switch to ABS or PET.

There are 2 bases included. The first one I designed for a #6 flat screw as I am mounting it to wood. I also included a base for M4 Flat screws so this could be mounted to the back of a monitor ( I have not tested the M4 yet ).

The feet will accommodate up to a Flat M4 screw.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:120441

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=120441

Using the following options:

split_bearing = No
outer_diameter = 22
inner_diameter = 15.875
sidewall_thickness = 2
height = 100

Printable parts for the CoreXY Frame based on the concept from FABtotum (without crossing belts).

!!! Prototype. Not tested.
Ver.2.1 for 5mm slot 2020 extrusion: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266282
Extruder mount:
Titan: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2253311
Custom: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664121
Laser: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2685298
CAD: https://grabcad.com/library/corexy-frame-v-2-0-1
Ver.1.0: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1811983

20x20 aluminium profile 6mm slot for a 5mm slot search ver.2.1 in my Things
MGN12 linear rail 3 pcs. + MGN12-H/C carriage block 3 pcs. (Ref. link: http://ali.pub/vnk2s)
// for MGN9 rail + MGN9-H/C search "v2_X_bot_plate_MGN9_LR.STL"
GT2 6mm belt
(length depends of the desired work area - calculations on the picture)

GT2 pulley 20 teeth 2 pcs.
F694ZZ ball bearing 16 pcs.
2020 internal L-joint 4 pcs.

4x 40mm countersunk M4 screws (gantry)
4x 25mm countersunk M4 screws (gantry idler bearings)
10x 10mm buttontop M4 screws (motor mounts, corner idler bearing mounts, gantry rail mounts)
2x 30mm socketcap M4 screws (corner idler bearings)
2x M4 0.5mm washers (corner idler bearings)
8x M4 Nuts (gantry idler bearings)
8x 10mm buttontop M3 screws (NEMA17 motors)
8x 6mm buttontop M3 screws (MGN12H linear rail)

There are also 2 pins that are 26mm long x 4mm diameter which is placed through the bottom of the corner idler bearing mounts and are what the bearing spin on, and is held in place in the part by the aluminum extrusion when it's screwed down. No idea where to get something like this, but you could always take a 26mm M4 screw and dremel off the head of the screw.
(For the 26mm pins you can use also 26mm pieces of 4mm welding electrode with coating material removed. Or https://www.amazon.com/26mm-6325-Dowel-Alloy-Steel/dp/B01I0BDG06)
(Many thanks for BOM to Turner Hayes http://www.thingiverse.com/tomasro/)

comments.text: I used all the X-axis parts for a custom CoreXY build I made (Used openbuild's metal NEMA17 motor mounts and metal pulley mounts instead of the ones here). Works great. I had a little trouble with the titan extruder mount you provide here (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2253311). It required a bit of filing to slide the 2 pieces together and the 2 slide in nuts were a little tight (ended up heating them with a soldering iron and pushing them in, which worked for the most part). The other issue is that the face (which extends all the way down, where you slide the bottom against is a little thin... and since the fit between the 2 was so tight, I broke a couple before I got it right (didn't want to over-file and end up with a loose connection, but if it was just a little too tight, was impossible to get out without breaking the main piece... which isn't the quickest re-print either). But using your extruder mount was intended to only be temporary, just for the initial build... I really want to mount 2 titans (probably 1 normal, 1 mirrored).... and connect it to a chimera/cyclops.... or if I can figure out a clean way to do it, just run a dual titan aero (1 mirrored)... but that might be a little harder due to the 20x20 rail under the x-axis. Gonna try to figure this out soon, I really want to run dual extruders, and hoping to do direct drive (seems to be much more reliable and gives you more filament options than dealing with a bowden setup).

comments.text: 16t pulleys work fine for me.  Also, while obv totally up to you, in my experience, 20x20 definitely does the job more than well enough... I have roughly 500mm sides, and have no problems at all.  I had originally thought of going 30x30, or 20x40 (at least in some spots), but after building with purely 20x20... I don't see the need.  Given, I went a little overboard on all my hardware bracing the 20x20 together (probably have 2 times what I need to do the job), but cant hurt.... that's also the route I'd recommend, if you are worried about rigidity, just brace the frame together a little more than necessary.
comments.author: DarthOctane

comments.text: agreed 2020 is fine. I have just already built a Hypercube Evolution (uses 3030) and this would basically drop right on top. I am a fan of overengineering things :-)
comments.author: progrock

comments.text:
Haha, makes total sense.... I definitely have been over engineering these as well
(using about 4 times the bracing I probably need... but this this is as solid as a rock). I might actually be getting some 20x40 for my next upgrade, considering adjusting a few of my mounts to make everything internal (ie the motors and the corner pulley mounts that I'm using)... that way I can pretty much just bolt on some plexiglass sides and make this thing fully enclosed. I've learned that having even heat distribution is one of the MOST important things, especially for larger prints.... I made the mistake of buying a knock-off keenovo silicon heater my first time.... I both replaced that with a REAL Keenovo heater (highly recommended, and you def want to order directly from them, otherwise chances are its not a real one) and got a much thicker aluminum be (full 1/4" this time).... huge improvement. If I enclose this thing, should make printing certain materials (especially Nylons) much easier.

description.text:
Pen plotter for Anet A8, and a simple way to print pictures on pieces of paper

This youtube video describes the process very well

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oP3jkoEJSa4

Here is my Video

https://youtu.be/Z1OPxMJlRos

Download 2D image to STL Converter (windows) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66115

open image inside program

Target Size (custom to the size of the image you want)

Target Height: 0.2 (or the layer height you have set in cura for your printer)

Add Base: 0

Spike filter and Anti Spike filter all the way to the left

Create STL

Now time for Cura settings. Open up Cura and save your previous profile by going to file, save profile.

settings on cura:
enable retraction, set minimum extrusion before retraction (mm) to 0 and z hop when retracting (mm) to 1

Printing temperature :0, bed temperature: 0

my print speed is set to 50mm/s

open up expert settings and remove the skirt by setting the line count under skirt to 0

now to to G Code and replace everything with these commands :

;Sliced at: {day} {date} {time}
;Basic settings: Layer height: {layer_height} Walls: {wall_thickness} Fill: {fill_density}
;Print time: {print_time}
;Filament used: {filament_amount}m {filament_weight}g
;Filament cost: {filament_cost}
;M190 S{print_bed_temperature} ;Uncomment to add your own bed temperature line
;M109 S{print_temperature} ;Uncomment to add your own temperature line
G21 ;metric values
G90 ;absolute positioning
M82 ;set extruder to absolute mode
M107 ;start with the fan off
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
G28 Z0 ;move Z to min endstops
G1 Z15.0 F{travel_speed} ;move the platform down 15mm
G92 Z14
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length
G1 F200 E3 ;extrude 3mm of feed stock
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length again
G1 F{travel_speed}
;Put printing message on LCD screen
M117 Printing...

now your ready to print, save to SD card or upload to Octoprint, use some binder clips or tape to hold down a piece of paper and 2D print with your 3D printer.

Some recommendations, the pen is offset from the extruder so move everything up on Cura so the pen doesn't start drawing off the platform. Also save this profile when your done creating it so you don't need to change the settings all the time. Also start the printer and insert the pen once it starts printing so you don't get a line across your print and also this sets the pen to the proper height for printing.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will need an M3 screw and M3 nut

remixed_from.author: TheRavenMaker
remixed_from.title: Dial Indicator Mount for Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Prusa

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1260597

This is for people who may not have any M6 hardware and are happy using the lower hole to mount the indicator. I have a good selection of M3 hardware.

There are now two versions, one that mostly uses TheRavenMaker’s design, and another that incorporates changes suggested by MKSA.

Version 1:
This remix is TheRavenMaker’s design with posts to accommodate M3 screws.

For this version you need to print one of these and one of TheRavenMaker’s.

Version 2:
As noted above, this version incorporates the changes suggested by MKSA where there is no firm grip of the bar, only the weight of the indicator is holding it in place, and only at 3 points. This is designed for an 8mm upper and lower bar. Two points make contact with the upper bar, and one point to keep it vertical with the lower bar.
The prints for this version start with "MKSA" and you need to print an A and a B version. The A version contains the posts.

Hardware: (2) M3 x 20 screws, (2) M3 nuts, (4) M3 washers.

Ream out the 3.2 and 6mm holes after printing. I would also suggest applying a very small mount of lube to the posts so that they come apart easily.

I’m using it on an Anet A8. The rail spacing doesn’t appear to be the same as the TheRavenMaker’s Wanhao Duplicator, but it works fine.

See wecapp's article and video to see the mount in use: https://meinelektronikhobby.blogspot.de/2017/03/gemessen-und-fur-gut-befunden.html

Update: After using both versions for a while, version 1, the one that grips the bar, performs better in terms of repeatability and general use. Version 2 moves too much, it has to be reseated when you move the bed back and forth.

The indicator I'm using: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10-0-01mm-Precision-Tool-Great-Micrometer-Measuring-Gauging-Tools-Round-Dial-Indicator-Gauge-Vertical-Contact/32607193924.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Ie616R

comments.text:
OK, but you should reduce the round at the top. It must be like a V block used in metrology, the top smooth rod must touch the two flat surfaces, not the round as ii is uncertain. See : http://www.fowlerprecision.com/Products/V-Blocks/.
The other smooth rod touchs the vertical surface. Here you have a repeatable properly constrained set up.
The surfaces must be finished to be flat with no burr.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
The round top makes no contact with the rod, only the two flat surfaces touch the rod, so I'm not removing it. It's designed for an 8mm rod.
I added a diagram to make it easier for you to understand (see the PNG).
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: OK, it is the way the rod must touch. Just that without a round, you can use a square file to finish both contact surfaces to remove ridges and burrs.
comments.author: JMadison

comments.text: How about repeatability with such a set up ????
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Why don't you design one like that and see how it performs?  On my Anet A8 the bottom is simply keeping it vertical, it doesn't fully engage with the bottom rail.  If I pinch the top so that it fully engages, and is perpendicular with the bed, it's reasonably reproducible.  A V profile on the top AND something to hold it tight/lock it into the top rail would be good.  The top V groove should probably be wider than this design to make it easier to keep it perpendicular.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Listen, no need to make yours as it is wrong and besides I have done one as I said in the past  ! Yeah, yours works somewhat but doesn't comply to isostatic rules !

comments.text: Maybe I will.  You could be a bit more diplomatic with your wording, someone could get the idea that you're arrogant.  This is a remix I made because I didn't have the hardware needed for the original design.  Nothing more than that.  I needed something to hold a dial indicator, found one that might work, added posts to fit the hardware I had on hand.

description.text:
The Avenger Class is an early 23rd Century destroyer designed by Masao Okazani(whose Paris Class later became the Archer Class scout). More information on this ship can be found here:

http://www.starfleet-museum.org/avenger-predator.htm

I made this as faithfully as possible based on Masao's orthographic drawings. The only main change I made is that I added warp grills to the inside of the engines. It's interestingly new yet recognizably "Star Trek". Even though it's non-canon, it's a very great design and hopefully gets tossed in to canon like the Archer was.

This is actually to scale with the rest of my models with the exception of the Archer Class.

This is a bottle rocket launcher, to be used with a Gardena bottle cap. I used this one:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148310

This thing requires a retaining clip bent out of 2mm wire, a car tyre pump and a board to mount it to.

I ran a drill through the clip holes to make sure they were nice and round so the clip was easy to pull out. The Block was then mounted to a sheet of MDF I had lying around. I also drilled 4 holes near the corners of the board so that I could peg it down to stop it moving when the clip was pulled out with a length of string.

The pump is attached to the lug on the side (it needs to stay attached during use as there's no valve in the base). The Gardena connector goes in the top and the retaining clip is pushed though the two small holes to retain the connector. I lubricated the connector with some Vaseline to improve air-tightness and to, well, lubricate it.

Early test assembly showing connector, pump and clip in place. Close up with fins added to bottle. (Fin brackets: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2139616)

remixed_from.author: muegen
remixed_from.title: V-Slot Openbuilds Mini Gantry E3D V6 mount W/ 18mm Proximity Sensor

title: V-Slot Mini Gantry E3Dv6 mount W/ 18mm Proximity Sensor W/ Integrated Fanduct

description.text:
!!!Important!!!
The current fanduct is about 6mm too short and blows against the heaterblock (had faulty measurements when designing this thing). I hope to find time soon to finish my build and to measure the exact needed length of the fanduct. Than i will upload an updated version off it. I am also planning to make the same kind off fanduct to be used in conjunction with a volcano nozzle.

For my own build i needed a carriage and found the original from Muegen interesting but not fully to my needs. Previously on my prusa I3 i used a setup from Tech2C which has a integrated fanduct and was really happy with it, so i wanted to integrate that same principal into the new one. (that file is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847)
It is meant to be used on the OpenBuilds V-Slot Mini Gantry plate, with a E3Dv6 Hotend and a 18mm Inductive sensor.

This thing will fit a boxed fan with an opening of 15x20mm on the outsides.
You might need to widen the gap a little bit as it might be a snug fit.
Also on some (well mine did) boxed fans there is a small notch on the mouth, this needs to be cut off otherwise it won't fit.

The changes i made compared to the original file(s):

  • Thickend the mounting plate from 4mm to 6mm
  • Integrated a slot for the upper nut of the proximity sensor for easier adjustment
  • Put the mount for proximity sensor a little higher, so the plastic is less close to the nozzle
  • Lengthened the hotend mount, to fit a fanduct through it
  • Made holes with m3 thread to fixate the fanduct (2x m3x6 or m3x8 needed)
  • Added an mount to fixate a boxed fan on top of the carriage (m4x25 + nut needed)
  • Remixed the fanduct from Tech2C by shortening it a little, and relocated the mounts

Update(s)

  • I have added a .stl file for an endstop mount to fit onto the 20x20 rail.
    It can be used with this hotend mount and with the filtered endstops (the ones on a pcb).

Printer:

improved Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Mountplate:
Printed with 4 perimeters, 4 solids top, 4 solids bottom and 20% fast honeycomb infill.
Support is optional but easier to bridge, so i did use supports.

Clamp:
Printed with 4 perimeters, 4 solids top, 4 solids bottom and 20% fast honeycomb infill.
When printing the top onto the bed, supports not needed.

Fanduct:
Printed with 2 perimeters, 2 solids top, 2 solids bottom.
I print it standing up without supports inside, only 2 pilars on the outside for supporting the mounts that are sticking out. You may put pilars underneath the "mouth" for easier bridging.

  • This part can be printed laying down but might need supports which will be pretty hard to remove and as the shell is so thing it might crack trying to do so.

author: ChatToBrian

title: Locking Dock for iPhone 6+ in Griffin Survivor Case

description.text:
This is a dock for an iPhone 6+ in a Griffin Survivor case. It allows use of headphones and an apple lightning adapter while docked. And the headphones are on a slide with a toggle lever, so that I can quickly disconnect them(to pause my music with one quick action).
The dock locks the iPhone in place and a lever at the back unlocks and then undocks the phone, straight out so the connectors are not damaged.
The rubber covers of the lightning and headphone jack are gone from my griffin case, having broken off from repeated open-close use. I imagine they would get in the way if still there.

I can't imagine too many other people would want a dock like this, since the phone is old, and the case normally precludes such use. But the source is included.

Vitamin use is rather extensive. 624 bearing, odd lengths of 20mm extrusion, M3, M4, and M5 screws in various sizes. I designed around what I had in my surplus bins. Also some of the parts are very large, and might not be printable on a normal 3d printer. My second printer has a very large build volume and an e3d volcano nozzle, so some parts were designed to take advantage of that.

This is used to attach a 1/4bsp gauge and pressure coupling to a PET bottle. The goal is to use the bottle as a reservoir to prevent the gauge from vibrating as measurements are made.

The outlet is a convergent nozzle.

Enlarge nozel until there's ~0.9 bar in the bottle. The output flow into atmosphere is then about the speed of sound. From that and the area of the enlarged hole, you know the flow of a compressor, through the connecting hoses at 0.9 bar.

If anyone at all makes this, then they run the risk of over pressuring the bottle. While they're probably good for 10 bar. Don't do that. Stick with really low pressure and a small fizzy drinks bottle. That minimises risk and stored energy.

To seal it use epoxy.

Use at own risk.

remixed_from.author: droftarts
remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

title: ANET A8 | Belt Pulley Insert (Customizable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Based on poor_red_neck's idea / thing and the parametric pulley lib of droftarts, I created a customizable belt pulley insert with belt retainers. I added some code to the pulley lib of droftarts in order to adapt it to the ANET A8's bearing.

Major credit goes to those two creators!

The reason for creating this thing was that the other versions did not provide retainers or the retainers were too tight and blocking the belt.

By using the customizer, a version without retainers or without support can be generated!



Why should I add a pulley insert to the bearing?
The tooths of the stock ANET A8 version are running on the plain surface of the bearing. This can cause vibrations to the motion of the y- and x-axis!



Spotlight on some CUSTOMIZER-configurations:

  • Default (Pulley T Ht = 6.5, Retainer Ht = 1.5, Notch Depth = 1)[AVAILABLE IN DOWNLOADS SECTION]:

    • Wider than stock standalone bearing (about 1.5mm)
    • Left some tolerance for belt (6mm wide)
    • Retainers should be more sturdy, since 0.5mm support before notch starts

  • Slim (Pulley T Ht = 6, Retainer Ht = 1.1, Notch Depth = 1):

    • Just minimally wider than stock standalone bearing (about 0.2mm)
    • No tolerance for belt (6mm wide) -> May stress the retainers
    • Retainers fragile, since only 0.1mm support before notch starts
  • Your awesome config here
    • You think you found an awesome configuration, just let me know in the comments and I may reference you here in the description

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12

Notes:

Print slow for high precision (e.g. 30-40mm/s)

Post print:

  • Remove the support on one side of the pulley (e.g. with a knive)
  • Do not tighten the screw holding the bearing too much (keep it loose in order to allow a frictionless rotation)!

comments.text:
For those having problems downloading a customised model in Customizer:
FIX:
When in Customizer mouse over to the top right of the preview window and click "View Source".
In the window that pops up select all text, right click and hit "Copy".
Open a new Notepad file on your Windows PC and paste the copied text.
Save as "YourFileNameHere.scad" <- This creates an .scad file.
Go to: http://www.openscad.org/
Download SCAD for FREE and install.
Open SCAD, click "File" and "Open".
Browse to your newly created .scad file and open it.
In the right hand window you'll see the code that generates your object.
Anytime you edit anything in the code, be sure you mouse to the top of that window and click "Preview" or hit F5 on your keyboard.
If the object creator is nice, every parameter of your customizable model will have a clear comment as to what changing that parameter will do.
When your done customizing the model click "Export to STL" at the top of the window.

You can use this holder to hook up and hold in place the flexible hose preventing it from spinning around due to the change of water pressure especially if the original hook is worn out and therefore too loose.

The bigger hollow has a diameter of 2.5cm (0.98 inches) and the smaller one 1.4cm (0.55 inches) which should be the pretty standard size to fit between the (round) shower column and the hose.

Chirrut Imwe's Staff! I've gone rogue, I wanted to do something for Rogue One and with no new lightsabers, Chirrut's staff was a great choice. This is a large print, measuring about 52 inches long, but it is straight forward.

I did not use any support for this print and all of the STLs are in the orientation I printed them. The male/female joints have very tight tolerances, so depending on how well your printer is calibrated/leveled you may need to sand or carve around the female end for fit.

title: Quick Change Toilet Paper Holder Remix

description.text:
I am quite enamored of DRAGONATORs Toilet Paper Holder. It is a well-thought-out design. The special cylinders that don't need support material was an epiphany.

This set of models, solves a few issues.

  • All of the pieces are rotated correctly for proper printing.
  • They are all centered on the build plate.
  • I have added a long pin model that can replace the 30mm screws
  • Additional models have been added to yield two parts with one print

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I recommend...

  • Filament = PLA 1.75mm
  • Temp = 200/60
  • Infill = .2
  • Shells = 2
  • FeedRate = 50/50

  • No Raft/Support

    • SideLeft = 5.5 hours, about 25 meters filament
    • SideRight = 5.5 hours, about 25 meters filament
    • Lid = 4.5 hours, about 19 meters of filament
    • LidPin = 0.2 hours, about .5 meters of filamant
    • Pin = 0.5 hours, about 1.5 meters filament
  • FeedRate = 30/30

  • No Raft/support

    • LongPin = 0.5 hours, about 1.2 meters filament

If you have trouble printing the long pins, I suggest a slower speed, and use a raft.

Most of the people I have talked to, suggest that the lid is not needed.
In retrospect the lid helps hold the tp in place.
i could see putting a weight of some sort on top of it.

After everything is printed, use the long pins to hold the larger pins in place.
The long pins are an intentional snug fit. Push them in with your finger, and when everything is seated properly, put a piece of wood over it, and tap it in tight with a hammer.
